name: Manchester Civil War Defences — Rosworm's Fortifications (1642-44)
description: Colonel John Rosworm's defensive earthworks around Manchester during the Civil War. A German military engineer, he designed ramparts, ditches, and sconces (small forts) around the town perimeter.
notes:
RESEARCH TARGET: Find reconstruction of Rosworm's defence line.

John Rosworm (also Rossworm/Rosworme), German military engineer.
Hired by Manchester Parliamentarians to design town defences.
Built a circuit of earthwork defences including:
- Mud ramparts with external ditch
- Sconces (small angular forts) at key positions
- Gates/barriers on all approach roads
- River crossings fortified

The defence line roughly followed:
- Hanging Ditch (medieval ditch, reused)
- Along Deansgate
- Around the Collegiate Church
- Down to the river

Rosworm published 'Good Service Hitherto Ill Rewarded' (1649) complaining about
non-payment — this text describes the fortifications in detail.
Available in Chetham Society publications.

Possible sources for plans:
- Chetham Society: 'The Civil War in Lancashire' series
- 'Manchester during the Civil War' by local historians
- GMAU may have mapped the earthwork traces
- Compare defensive line with street pattern on 1650 plan
- Proceedings of Lancashire & Cheshire Antiquarian Society
